thread.title: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger says Sutton's artificial pitch is biggest threat to FA Cup hopes
thread.title_full: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger says Sutton's artificial pitch is biggest threat to FA Cup hopes

author: Ben Rumsby
title: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger says Sutton's artificial pitch is biggest threat to FA Cup hopes
text:
Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger says Sutton's artificial pitch is biggest threat to FA Cup hopes Wenger has had his team train indoors in preparation for Monday's match at Sutton Credit: Getty Images Ben Rumsby  30pm 
A rsene Wenger was leaving nothing to chance when it came to Sutton United’s plastic pitch on Sunday night as he sought to avoid an FA Cup shock that would almost certainly end any prospect of him remaining at Arsenal. 
Wenger admitted the artificial surface at Gander Green Lane was one of the primary dangers to his side’s hopes of rescuing their season, outlining the Gunners’ strategy of training indoors in order to acclimatise to it ahead of Monday's fifth-round tie. 
So concerned was Wenger about the pitch that Danny Welbeck, who would have been in line to continue his comeback from injury by starting this evening, was given a run-out for the club’s under-23 team yesterday instead of being risked at Sutton. 
It was therefore hard to see defender Laurent Koscielny featuring either after he limped off in Wednesday’s 5-1 Champions League thrashing at Bayern Munich with a hamstring injury that needed a scan on Friday. 
Admitting even training indoors would not fully prepare his players for what awaited them tonight, Wenger said: “It is not the same because it [Arsenal’s] is a dry pitch and Sutton, I have heard, have a wet pitch, which they water before the game and is quicker. Sutton's Gander Green Lane has an artificial pitch Credit: PA 
“The weight on the joints is different and you cannot slide to block every time, so it makes football a bit different. 
“The ball comes to you suddenly and accelerates and does not slow down like in a normal game, so we have to get used to the different speed.” 
H e added: “Ideally, we would like to play on a normal pitch but it has been accepted and the competition is to deal with what you face. 
“We will face an unusual pitch and we will have to deal with it.” Sports greatest ever upsets, featuring Lincoln beating Burnley 
W elbeck, who starred on his first start of the season in Arsenal’s fourth-round thrashing of Southampton last month, took to Twitter yesterday to confirm his unavailability after continuing his comeback from a long-term knee injury: Glad to get 70 minutes today to build up my match fitness. Plastic pitch at Sutton isn't the best idea at the moment. #COYG — Danny Welbeck (@DannyWelbeck) February 19, 2017 
A s well as the pitch, Wenger said Arsenal would have to cope with the “enthusiasm” of FA Cup giant killers whose run to the fifth round has captured the imagination. 
He also said the Gunners would pay the price if they were “not ready for a big fight and subconsciously think that they are a non-league team”, but added: “That will not happen.” 
Wenger had already indicated he would pick a strong side and was given every incentive to do so yesterday when the winners of the tie were drawn at home against the other non-league club left in the competition, Lincoln City . 
His team could therefore include star striker Alexis Sanchez, who cut a frustrated figure again at the Allianz Arena on Wednesday and was given the rest of the week off to deal with a tax fraud court case in Barcelona. 
Wenger suggested the Chilean – who has stalled over signing a new contract – needed to look at his own performance before aiming critical glances at his team-mates. 
“I do not want to comment individually but we have lost as a team and Alexis is part of that,” the Arsenal manager said. 
W enger denied the Bayern defeat would make Sanchez less likely to extend his contract beyond next year but admitted his own future would be determined by results for the rest of the season – starting tonight. 
The Frenchman last week announced he would not retire this summer and would “definitely” manage elsewhere if he left Arsenal . 
But he also admitted his preference was to stay with the Gunners rather than take his first new job for more than 20 years. 
Asked what Arsenal’s players could do to help him decide to sign a new contract of his own, he said: “That will not depend on the players, it will depend on the results.”
